questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
When two male crickets encounter each other there is either a fight or a threat display. The dominant cricket usually forces the submissive cricket to retreat to a place of safety. A biologist conducted two experiments to investigate the formation of dominance hierarchies (rankings) in male crickets. In the experiments described below, five adult male crickets were placed together in a container, and their interactions were observed and recorded.

Experiment 1
To determine what factors might affect the formation of dominance hierarchies, the biologist recorded the sequence in which the crickets were placed in the container, their masses, their adult ages, and the number of chirps each cricket made during the experiment. In addition, the crickets were ranked according to their aggressiveness toward each other, from most aggressive (1) to least aggressive (5). The results are shown in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The crickets were placed back into the container in the same sequence as in Experiment 1. The results of all aggressive encounters between pairs of crickets were recorded. A cricket was declared a "winner" if it forced the other cricket, the "loser," to retreat. Table 2 shows the results of the interactions between the crickets.


Table 3 summarizes the results of all the encounters for each cricket.
questions.question: 1. Which of the following generalizations about the rela­tionship between cricket mass and position in the dom­inance hierarchy is consistent with the experimental results ?

choices.A: The smallest cricket will be the most dominant.
choices.B: The largest cricket will be the most submissive.
choices.C: The largest cricket will be the most dominant.
choices.D: Weight has no effect on position in the hierarchy.

questions.question: 2.  It was suggested that the more dominant a male  cricket was, the more resources, such as food, that cricket would acquire. Accordingly, one would predict, based on win-loss records, that the cricket which would obtain the LEAST amount of food would be:

choices.B: Cricket C.
choices.C: Cricket D.
choices.D: Cricket E.

questions.question: 3.  A sixth cricket, whose mass was 0.2 grams and whose adult age was 3 days was added to the experimental container. questions.title: Passage Ⅱ
questions.article:
Global warming can occur when solar radiation passes through the atmosphere, heats Earth's surface, and is then re-emitted as longer wavelength infrared radiation. This infrared radiation can be trapped by "greenhouse gases" in the atmosphere as it leaves Earth's surface, gradually increasing global temperatures. Greenhouse gases include water vapor, carbon dioxide (CO2), methane, ozone, and chlorofluorocarbons.

Two scientists present their views on global warming.

Scientist 1
In the past 30 years, increased use of coal and oil and the burning of forests have steadily increased atmospheric CO2. Burning coal and oil releases 5.6 billion tons of CO2 per year; burning forests adds another 0.4 to 2.5 billion tons and also decreases the amount of plants that would remove CO2 from the air during photosynthesis. This increase of CO2 in the air has increased global average temperatures and caused Arctic ice to melt. One result of continued global warming will be rising sea levels due to large-scale melting of ice in polar areas.

Scientist 2
CO2 has not caused global warming. In the past 30 years, human activity has released not only CO2, but large amounts of dust and aerosol particles into the atmosphere. These particles reflect large amounts of incoming solar radiation back into space before it reaches Earth's surface. This actually cools Earth slightly. From 1938 to 1976, studies showed that global average temperatures were falling while CO2 levels were increasing.

Ice ages occurred every 2,500 years and were separated by warmer periods. Even though CO2 levels were higher during the warmer periods than during the ice ages, the ice ages occurred regardless of the CO2 levels in the atmosphere. During the most recent warmer period 1,000 years ago, the global average temperature was 1° to 3.5°C above that of today but the CO2 levels were much lower than today's levels. Changes in the CO2 levels in the past were a result of the temperature changes, not a cause of them.
questions.question: 7. According to Scientist 1, which of the following figures best represents the global temperature and CO2 relationship over the past 30 years?

questions.question: 8. Which of the following would Scientist 1 suggest to solve the problem of global warming?

choices.A: Reforest large areas of the planet
choices.B: Increase the use of coal and oil
choices.C: Reduce the number of nuclear power plants
choices.D: Increase the production of chlorofluorocarbons

questions.question: 9. Volcanic eruptions can release large amounts of ash into the atmosphere and often cause slight global cooling. This information would best support the view of:

choices.A: Scientist 1, because increased CO2 in the atmosphere causes global cooling.
choices.B: Scientist 1, because increased CO2 in the atmosphere causes global warming.
choices.C: Scientist 2, because increased dust in the atmosphere causes global cooling.
choices.D: Scientist 2, because increased dust in the atmosphere causes global warming.

questions.question: 10.  According to the hypothesis of Scientist 1, which of the following results is expected if burning of forests increases?

choices.A: CO2 levels in the atmosphere would decrease rapidly.
choices.B: There would be a decrease in global average temperature.
choices.C: The ocean levels would gradually rise.
choices.D: Particle levels in the atmosphere would decrease.

questions.question: 11.  The views of both scientists are similar because they imply that:

choices.A: changes in atmospheric temperature occur almost instantly after CO2 is added.
choices.B: the atmosphere's composition and average temperature remain constant over thousands of years.
choices.C: the destruction of more forests could bring on an ice age sooner than expected.
choices.D: there is a correlation between atmospheric temperature and materials added to the atmosphere by human activity.

questions.question: 13.  The hypothesis of Scientist 2 could best be tested by:

choices.A: analyzing data on wind speeds in the atmosphere for the past 50 years.
choices.B: taking air temperature over the poles during the next 5 years.
choices.C: measuring high-altitude wind speeds in polar areas.
choices.D: measuring air temperature changes in greenhouses with different levels of airborne particles.

questions.title: Passage Ⅲ
questions.article:
Gas effusion occurs when a gas moves through a tiny opening into a region of lower pressure. The rate in milliliters per second (mL/sec) is measured using the apparatus in Figure 1.


A 25 mL gas sample in a syringe freely escapes into a flask. The molecular mass, in a.m.u. (atomic mass units), for seven gases and the time required to completely effuse are recorded in Table 1. The densities (mass/volume) in grams per liter (g/L) and average molecular speed (average distance traveled by a molecule per second) in meters per second (m/sec) are also given.


Figure 2 shows a graph of the effusion rate versus the molecular mass of the gases.
questions.question: 14. Given the information in Table 1, the difference in effusion times is greatest between which of the following pairs of gases?

choices.B: NH3 and CO2
choices.C: NH3 and SO2
choices.D: Air and O2

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
A study was conducted to determine whether two test kits (Kit A and Kit B) provided reliable data on the content of water samples of varying salinity (salt concentration). The concentrations of several compounds commonly tested for in water samples were measured. The results are presented in the table below. The results for the test kits were compared to estimates obtained using Standard Methods, which provide extremely accurate estimates.


Table adapted from Claude E. Boyd and Harry V. Daniels, "Evaluation of Hach Fish Farmer's Water Quality Test Kits for Saline Water." ©1988 by the World Aquaculture Society.
questions.question: 19. From the results, one would conclude that at a salinity of 0 ppt, Kit A is most accurate in measuring the concentration of which of the following compounds, relative to the Standard Method?

choices.B: Dissolved CO2
choices.C: Chloride
choices.D: CaCO3

questions.title: Passage Ⅳ
questions.article:
A study was conducted to determine whether two test kits (Kit A and Kit B) provided reliable data on the content of water samples of varying salinity (salt concentration). The concentrations of several compounds commonly tested for in water samples were measured. The results are presented in the table below. The results for the test kits were compared to estimates obtained using Standard Methods, which provide extremely accurate estimates.


Table adapted from Claude E. Boyd and Harry V. Daniels, "Evaluation of Hach Fish Farmer's Water Quality Test Kits for Saline Water." ©1988 by the World Aquaculture Society.
questions.question: 23.  A water sample of unknown salinity was tested using Kit A. The concentrations, in mg/L, of selected compounds in this sample were: dissolved O2 = 7.1, CaCO3 = 69.0, and NH3 = 0.65. According to the data in the table, one would predict that the most likely level of salinity was:

choices.B: 3 ppt.
choices.C: 15 ppt.
choices.D: 25 ppt.

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
Moving water can shape sediment into bedforms, such as ripples (narrow ridges separated by wider troughs). A geologist performed 3 studies to examine bedforms.

Study 1
Samples were taken from 4 layers of a'n exposed section of sandstone and the average sample grain diameter, in millimeters (mm), was measured. Any bedforms preserved in the sections were recorded. The results are shown in Table 1.


Study 2
A sediment sample was taken at 5 sites across the stream shown in Figure 1. The average grain diameter of each sample was determined and any bedforms at the site were noted. The water depth and velocity, in centimeters per second (cm/sec), were measured at Sites 3, 4, and 5. The results are shown in Table 2.



Study 3

A stream channel was built that contained 20 cm deep flowing water. Three experiments were done, each using a flat layer of a different sediment grain diameter. The bed-forms created by flowing water of various velocities were recorded for each experiment. The results are shown in Table 3. "Flat bed" means sediment movement but no ripples. "NM" means no sediment movement.
questions.question: 24. If gravel is any sediment with a grain diameter of 2 mm or greater, what site in Study 2 had gravel sediment?

choices.B: Site 2
choices.C: Site 3
choices.D: Site 4

questions.question: 25. According to Study 3, sand would most likely be completely washed away by water moving at a velocity of:

choices.B: between 40 and 80 cm/sec.
choices.C: between 80 and 120 cm/sec.
choices.D: over 120 cm/sec.

"NM" means no sediment movement.
questions.question: 26.  Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of Studies 2 and 3 ?

choices.A: To demonstrate conditions that could create bed-forms similar to those found in the sandstone outcrop
choices.B: To determine the cross-sectional shape of the stream that originally deposited the sand found in the outcrop
choices.C: To measure the volume of water in a small river
choices.D: To identify the kinds of plants that lived at the time the sand was being changed to sandstone

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:

Study 3

A stream channel was built that contained 20 cm deep flowing water. Three experiments were done, each using a flat layer of a different sediment grain diameter. The bed-forms created by flowing water of various velocities were recorded for each experiment. The results are shown in Table 3. "Flat bed" means sediment movement but no ripples. "NM" means no sediment movement.
questions.question: 27. Closer examination of Section 1 in Study 1 revealed that the largest grains (up to 20 mm in diameter) were at the bottom of the section. According to the studies, which of the following statements best explains why such large grains were found at the bottom of the section?

choices.A: The water velocity at the time the sediment was deposited was high enough to carry away all but the largest grains.
choices.B: The water velocity at the time the sediment was deposited was too slow to carry away even the smallest grains.
choices.C: The water depth at the time the sediment was deposited was too shallow for large grains to settle to the bottom.
choices.D: The water depth at the time the sediment was deposited was too deep for large grains to settle to the bottom.

"NM" means no sediment movement.
questions.question: 28.  According to Study 3, which of the following is the best explanation for the presence of ripples at Site 2 in Study 2 ?

choices.A: Site 2 sediment once had an average grain diameter of 10 mm.
choices.B: Water moving at a velocity of 40 cm/sec once covered Site 2.
choices.C: Water moving at a velocity of 120 cm/sec once covered Site 2.
choices.D: Water 100 cm deep once covered Site 2.

questions.question: 29.  Another sample was taken from a sixth site in Study 2 that yielded the following data:According to this data and the data from Study 2, one could generalize that:

choices.A: large ripples only form in sediments having a diameter of 0.5 mm.
choices.B: large ripples only form in sediments having a diameter of 10 mm.
choices.C: water depth has no influence on the type of bed-form produced.
choices.D: water depth must be less than 50 cm before bed-forms will be created by moving water.

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article: Light causes some metals to eject electrons. The energy of those electrons, in joules (J), depends on the light frequency and the kind of metal. Figure 1 shows how the maximum energy of ejected electrons varies with frequency, in hertz (Hz), for 5 metals. Figure 2 shows how the number of electrons emitted by a metal varies with the intensity of light at a constant frequency. Figure 3 shows the maximum energy an ejected electron can have for a given intensity of light at a constant frequency.
questions.question: 30. Which of the following data is represented on the x-axis of Figure 2 ?

choices.B: Intensity of light
choices.C: Number of electrons emitted per second
choices.D: Maximum energy of emitted electrons

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article: Light causes some metals to eject electrons. The energy of those electrons, in joules (J), depends on the light frequency and the kind of metal. Figure 1 shows how the maximum energy of ejected electrons varies with frequency, in hertz (Hz), for 5 metals. Figure 2 shows how the number of electrons emitted by a metal varies with the intensity of light at a constant frequency. Figure 3 shows the maximum energy an ejected electron can have for a given intensity of light at a constant frequency.
questions.question: 31.  The hypothesis that turning on more light will increase the number of electrons emitted per second is supported by which figure(s)?(Note: Assume the additional light also has adequate energy to eject electrons from metals.)

choices.B: Figure 2 only
choices.C: Figure 3 only
choices.D: Figure 2 and 3 only

questions.question: 32.  Is the statement "The maximum energy of electrons increases with intensity" supported by the data in Figure 3 ?

choices.A: Yes, because the graph line moves to the right as the value of intensity increases.
choices.B: Yes, because the maximum energy of electrons increases as the value of intensity increases.
choices.C: No, because the same value for maximum energy is indicated for all values of intensity.
choices.D: No, because the line does not slope downward from left to right.

questions.question: 33. If the data in Figure 3 was produced by a light with a frequency of 6.5 x 1014 Hz, which metal was most likely used?

choices.B: Metal B
choices.C: Metal C
choices.D: Metal E

questions.question: 34.  According to the data, which of the following statements best compares the frequencies of light required for both Metals A and D to produce an electron with a maximum electron energy of 2 x 10-19 J ?

choices.A: The frequency required for Metal D is approximately one-quarter of that required for Metal A.
choices.B: The frequency required for Metal D is approximately half of that required for Metal A.
choices.C: The frequency required for Metal D is the same as that required for Metal A.
choices.D: The frequency required for Metal D is approximately twice that required for Metal A.

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article:
A student conducted experiments to determine the relationship between the musical pitch (frequency) of a vibrating string and its length, tension, and mass density (mass per unit length of string).

Experiment 1
The student cut several lengths of steel strings having different diameters. The strings were weighed and their mass densities calculated. Specified lengths of the strings were hung from the ceiling. A block was suspended from the free end of each string, making the tension in the string equal to the suspended weight in newtons (N). Plucking the string caused it to vibrate, producing sound waves. The sound waves were detected by a microphone and displayed on the screen of an oscilloscope, where the fundamental frequency of vibration, in cycles per second, or hertz (Hz), could be measured. The results are presented in Table 1.


Experiment 2
The student repeated the procedure in Experiment 1, using strings made of nylon and gut and having different diameters. The results are presented in Table 2.
questions.question: 35. The variable that is directly manipulated by the student between Trials 10 and 11 is the:

choices.B: frequency of the resulting vibration.
choices.C: material of which the string is composed.
choices.D: tension to which the string is subjected.

questions.question: 36.  Instead of attaching a block to the string in Trial 1, the student could have produced the same tension in the string by:

choices.A: increasing the length of the string to 3.0 m.
choices.B: pulling on the string with a force of 900 N.
choices.C: increasing the mass density to 20 g/m.
choices.D: plucking the string close to the ceiling.

questions.question: 37.  If the string used in Trial 10 were subjected to a tension of 3,600 N, the frequency of the resulting sound waves would be:

choices.B: 75 Hz.

questions.question: 38.  On the basis of both experiments, which of the following statements regarding the relationship between observed frequency of vibration and the other physical variables is, correct?

choices.B: Increasing mass density increases observed frequency.
choices.C: Increasing vibrating length increases observed frequency.
choices.D: The observed frequency depends on the material.

questions.question: 39.  A student is given several nylon strings of identical vibrating length but unknown mass densities. The string with the highest mass density could be found by:

choices.A: placing all the strings under identical tension and selecting the string with the highest frequency.
choices.B: placing all the strings under identical tension and selecting the string with the lowest frequency.
choices.C: tuning all the strings to the same frequency and selecting the string with the lowest tension.
choices.D: selecting the string capable of sustaining the highest frequency without breaking.

questions.question: 40.  On the Diatonic C major scale, a middle D note is taken to be 297 Hz. A guitarist wants to use a steel string of mass density 40 g/m with a tension of 3,600 N for the D string on a special type of guitar. Approximately what length of string should the guitarist use to produce a middle D note?
